title: Can AI Give a TED Talk? Testing the Limits of AI Inspiration
text:
What would an AI talk about if it were asked to give a TED Talk?
Would the talk captivate the audience or leave them wishing for a human speaker instead?
To find out, I decided to have an AI create a TED Talk script on a random topic and then evaluate whether it could hold the audience‚Äôs attention. The challenge: AI doesn‚Äôt live in the world, it doesn‚Äôt have personal experiences, and it lacks the human connection that makes a good TED Talk unforgettable. Could an AI still create something that might resonate with us?
Here‚Äôs the script AI generated for the TED Talk:

title: Can AI Give a TED Talk? Testing the Limits of AI Inspiration
section: ‚ÄúThe Power of Imperfection: Why We Should Celebrate Flaws
text:
‚ÄúThe Power of Imperfection: Why We Should Celebrate Flaws

Opening:
The lights go down. A soft but confident voice fills the room.
‚ÄúGood evening, everyone. I‚Äôm here to talk about something we all share: our imperfections. The very thing that we often hide, avoid, or criticize. What if I told you that embracing imperfection could be the key to living a more fulfilling life? A life that‚Äôs not about perfection or flawless performance, but about being unapologetically human.‚Äù
Pause for effect.
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs start with a story‚Äîimagine you‚Äôre watching a movie, and you‚Äôre totally immersed in it. The actors, the plot, the setting‚Äîit‚Äôs all perfect. But at some point, you notice a tiny mistake: an actor‚Äôs line is a little off, a prop falls out of place, or the lighting shifts in a way it shouldn‚Äôt. Suddenly, the perfect movie loses its charm. The illusion is shattered. Why? Because we, as humans, are conditioned to seek authenticity, not perfection. Perfection feels staged, unnatural. And it‚Äôs the flaws in the story that make it real.‚Äù
Pause.
‚ÄúNow think about your own life. How often do you focus on the things that aren‚Äôt quite right? The small mistakes at work, the little missteps in conversations, the imperfections in your appearance? What if, instead of focusing on those flaws, you embraced them as part of who you are?‚Äù


Middle:
The tone shifts to a more reflective, encouraging tone.
‚ÄúWe all strive for perfection‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs in our careers, relationships, or even on social media. But why do we feel the need to be perfect? It‚Äôs the fear of judgment, of not being good enough. But guess what? Everyone else is just as imperfect as you. In fact, it‚Äôs our imperfections that connect us. They create vulnerability, which leads to empathy. It‚Äôs why we relate to characters in movies who stumble, or to a friend who shares their struggles. It‚Äôs the rawness, the authenticity, that makes them memorable.‚Äù
Pause.
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs talk about mistakes for a moment. We often see mistakes as setbacks, as things we need to fix or hide. But what if mistakes were a gift? A lesson in disguise? In fact, some of the world‚Äôs most famous innovations were the result of mistakes. Penicillin was discovered by accident. Post-it notes were invented because of a failed adhesive. The greatest discoveries often come from those moments when things don‚Äôt go according to plan.‚Äù
Shift in tone.
‚ÄúSo, what if you started seeing your imperfections as strengths rather than weaknesses? What if you stopped apologizing for being ‚Äòimperfect‚Äô and instead celebrated those little things that make you‚Ä¶ you?‚Äù


Closing:
The voice becomes more hopeful, as if speaking directly to the audience.
‚ÄúImagine a world where we stop hiding our flaws. Where we embrace the moments that don‚Äôt go perfectly. A world where imperfection is not something to be ashamed of, but something to be proud of. The next time you feel imperfect, remember that imperfection is what makes you human. It‚Äôs what connects you to others. It‚Äôs what makes you memorable. And, most importantly, it‚Äôs what makes life beautiful.‚Äù
Pause.
‚ÄúThank you.‚Äù



Could AI Hold the Audience‚Äôs Attention?



ai-robot-digital-machines-_10565321.png


Not bad AI, it addresses a topic that‚Äôs relatable and introspective. The talk follows a logical structure, with a solid introduction, a well-supported middle, and a concluding message that encourages the audience to rethink how they view imperfection. But the big question remains: could an AI TED Talk hold the audience‚Äôs attention?


What Worked:

Relatable Topic:
The idea of embracing imperfection is universally relatable. It taps into something that everyone struggles with‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs body image, career setbacks, or personal flaws. Everyone has felt that desire to be perfect at some point, so the theme resonates.


Positive Message:
The theme of turning imperfections into strengths is uplifting. The talk encourages a shift in perspective, urging us to stop fearing mistakes and embrace the growth that comes from them. It‚Äôs a feel-good, motivational message that‚Äôs hard to dismiss.


Structure:
The talk is well-organized and easy to follow. AI has a strong understanding of how to craft a speech, using hooks, transitions, and a clear conclusion. It‚Äôs a testament to how well AI can mimic human-style speechwriting.



What Fell Short:

Lack of Personal Connection:
While the topic is relatable, the AI doesn‚Äôt bring personal experience into the speech. A human TED speaker might share a personal story of overcoming their own perfectionism or failing in a big way and learning from it. This personal vulnerability helps build a connection with the audience. AI, on the other hand, can‚Äôt speak from experience. The talk remains informative but feels a bit impersonal.


Emotional Depth:
One of the most powerful aspects of TED Talks is the emotional depth that human speakers bring. They inject passion, personal struggle, and authenticity into their words. AI, while capable of writing a coherent and logical speech, lacks the ability to truly embody emotion or vulnerability. It‚Äôs hard to get emotionally invested in a speech that‚Äôs generated by a machine.


Humor and Timing:
TED Talks often have moments of humor or wit that help break the tension and make the speaker more relatable. AI can create humor, but it doesn‚Äôt fully understand timing, delivery, or how to use humor in context. Without that nuanced touch, the speech might come off as more like a self-help article than a captivating live talk.

title: Can AI Give a TED Talk? Testing the Limits of AI Inspiration
section: The Purpose of a TED Talk:
text:
The Purpose of a TED Talk:



What-Is-A-TED-Talk_-Featured-Image-1.png


A TED Talk‚Äôs primary purpose is to inspire, inform, and engage an audience by presenting new ideas or perspectives in a compelling and thought-provoking way. TED (Technology, Entertainment, and Design) is known for hosting speakers from various fields‚Äîscience, art, psychology, business, and more‚Äîwho present groundbreaking ideas, share personal stories, or offer insights into the human condition.

Sharing a Big Idea:
TED speakers are often tasked with conveying an idea that challenges conventional thinking, inspires action, or presents a new way of understanding the world. It‚Äôs about sparking curiosity and leaving the audience with something to think about long after the talk is over.


Connection through Storytelling:
Personal stories are central to TED Talks. By sharing real-life experiences or lessons learned, speakers build a deeper emotional connection with their audience. Storytelling makes complex ideas more relatable, easier to digest, and often more memorable.


Engagement and Inspiration:
TED Talks aren‚Äôt just about information. They‚Äôre designed to engage and inspire. The best TED speakers infuse energy, passion, and authenticity into their presentations, making the audience feel emotionally invested in the subject.


Actionable Takeaways:
TED Talks aim to leave the audience with a clear, actionable takeaway‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs a new way of thinking, a challenge to take on, or an opportunity to make a change in their own lives or work. The speaker should spark curiosity, but also guide the audience toward practical steps they can take to apply the new knowledge.

title: Can AI Give a TED Talk? Testing the Limits of AI Inspiration
text:
Did AI Hit That Purpose?



download.png


When reviewing the AI-generated TED Talk script on ‚ÄúThe Power of Imperfection,‚Äù it‚Äôs clear that the AI made a valiant attempt at meeting the purpose of a TED Talk, but there were areas where it fell short.

Sharing a Big Idea:
The concept of embracing imperfection is undeniably a big idea‚Äîone that resonates with many people in today‚Äôs culture of perfectionism, especially with the rise of social media and constant self-optimization. The AI script presents this idea clearly, offering a fresh perspective on how imperfections can actually be strengths. In this sense, AI did succeed in offering a new way of thinking about something that‚Äôs very relatable.


Connection through Storytelling:
This is where AI misses the mark. While the speech was well-written and logical, it lacked a personal story. TED Talks are often memorable because of the personal, emotional connection a speaker can forge with their audience. A TED Talk about imperfection could have been much more impactful if the speaker had shared a personal failure or moment of vulnerability. It‚Äôs these stories that make ideas come alive. Without that personal touch, the talk feels somewhat like a lecture rather than a story-driven exploration of the theme.


Engagement and Inspiration:
While the AI script was motivational, it didn‚Äôt quite capture the emotional energy that a human TED speaker might bring. The best TED Talks often have a rhythm that builds and releases emotional tension‚Äîmoments of humor, passion, or surprise that keep the audience on their toes. AI can generate an inspiring message, but it lacks the nuance and timing required to truly engage the audience emotionally. For example, AI can‚Äôt alter its tone or delivery based on how the audience is reacting. It writes a speech that would work in theory, but the delivery is left to chance, without the dynamic adjustments a human speaker would make.


Actionable Takeaways:
The AI speech does offer actionable takeaways by encouraging the audience to embrace their imperfections, see mistakes as opportunities, and stop striving for unattainable perfection. These are valuable insights that could have a lasting impact on the audience if delivered with more emotion. However, it‚Äôs missing the powerful call-to-action that might inspire immediate change‚Äîsomething a human speaker could add by tailoring the message to the specific audience they‚Äôre addressing. For example, a human speaker might challenge the audience to share a story about a personal failure or imperfection, leading to a more interactive and powerful conclusion.

title: Can AI Give a TED Talk? Testing the Limits of AI Inspiration
section: SO‚Ä¶ Should we Put ChatGPT on Ted?
text:
SO‚Ä¶ Should we Put ChatGPT on Ted?



ted-talks-on-education-pic-scaled.jpg


AI certainly has the capacity to generate a TED Talk that presents a big idea and offers insightful observations. The structure and content are solid, and the message is inspirational. However, where AI falls short is in the realm of human connection‚Äîthe heart of what makes TED Talks so powerful. A key part of the TED Talk experience is the personal vulnerability and emotional energy that speakers bring to their presentation. AI, as impressive as it is at generating ideas and language, lacks the life experience, emotional depth, and interactive ability to truly engage an audience in the way a human speaker can.
While the AI version might be informative and even thought-provoking, it doesn‚Äôt have the human qualities that make a TED Talk memorable. In short, AI can deliver the core message, but the magic that makes TED Talks so impactful comes from the storyteller‚Äîsomething AI can replicate but not fully capture.

So, while it‚Äôs clear AI has the technical ability to write a TED Talk, it doesn‚Äôt quite hit the full mark when it comes to achieving the emotional and relational purpose that TED is known for.

title: AI‚Äôs Take on ‚ÄúWhat Makes a Good Joke?‚Äù: Can it Be Funny?
text:
We all know the formula: set-up, punchline, timing. But does AI understand this formula? I‚Äôve spent plenty of time laughing at Memes and Tiktoks but could a machine do the same? So, for the sake of science (and good humor), I decided to put AI to the test and see if it could make me laugh.
I asked our class LLM to generate jokes for me, and then I rates them on a scale of 1-10 for how funny they are

title: AI‚Äôs Take on ‚ÄúWhat Makes a Good Joke?‚Äù: Can it Be Funny?
section: What makes human comedy jokes different from AI jokes?
text:
What makes human comedy jokes different from AI jokes?
When it comes to human comedians, humor often comes with layers of personal experience, delivery, and a unique perspective on the world. Comedians like Dave Chappelle, Ali Wong, or John Mulaney have this uncanny ability to take everyday experiences and turn them into these deeply relatable, often profound, and always funny bits. Their timing is razor-sharp; they know how to pause, when to lean into a punchline, and how to give us just enough context to make the joke hit harder. It‚Äôs not just about the words‚Äîthey build tension, create expectations, and then surprise us.
For example, a classic Mulaney bit about being a kid is funny because of how he‚Äôs able to give such a detailed picture of a child‚Äôs brain, then tie that to a hilarious (yet completely believable) observation about growing up. The relatability, the self-deprecation, the storytelling‚Äîit all works together. The punchline isn‚Äôt just the final line; it‚Äôs the entire setup that takes us to an unexpected conclusion.
AI‚Äôs humor, on the other hand, lacks that lived experience and human understanding of the world. Its jokes are more mechanical. It pulls from patterns in language and existing jokes, often replicating humor we‚Äôve already heard‚Äîpuns, dad jokes, and one-liners. There‚Äôs a clear pattern to AI‚Äôs jokes: it thrives on wordplay and simple observations. Take the skeleton joke from earlier: ‚ÄúWhy don‚Äôt skeletons fight each other? Because they don‚Äôt have the guts.‚Äù The humor here is straightforward, but it‚Äôs almost too easy, too formulaic. The joke itself doesn‚Äôt come from a personal perspective or a twist on society‚Äîit‚Äôs based on a pun, which is an obvious play on words. It‚Äôs clever, but it doesn‚Äôt have the kind of depth or subtext that we get from human comics who inject their own experiences into their material.
AI doesn‚Äôt seem to understand why certain jokes are funnier based on the context in which they‚Äôre told. A human comedian will know exactly how to build a joke based on the energy of the crowd, the way the night‚Äôs going, or even their own mood. AI just spits out a punchline because that‚Äôs what it‚Äôs been trained to do. It doesn‚Äôt feel the rhythm or energy of humor‚Äîit just mimics.

title: AI‚Äôs Take on ‚ÄúWhat Makes a Good Joke?‚Äù: Can it Be Funny?
section: What makes AI jokes similar to human jokes?
text:
What makes AI jokes similar to human jokes?
 (The first ever AI powered stand up show)
Despite the differences, there‚Äôs still something strikingly similar between AI-generated jokes and those from comedians. Both rely on patterns that people find universally funny: puns, exaggeration, and absurdity. A lot of humor is rooted in the unexpected, and AI can certainly tap into this, albeit in a more structured way. For example, the AI-generated joke about procrastination and cat videos hit the mark because it‚Äôs a universal observation: people get distracted by cute animals instead of doing important things. It works because it‚Äôs true. And while a comedian might add their own flair to it, AI is still able to capture the essence of what makes it relatable.
In a way, AI‚Äôs jokes are similar to those found in early stand-up routines where the jokes are more about general observations rather than personal stories. It‚Äôs a kind of humor that exists without the depth of a specific experience, but that doesn‚Äôt mean it‚Äôs not funny. AI can capture the structure of humor pretty well, even if it doesn‚Äôt always understand the nuance.

title: AI‚Äôs Take on ‚ÄúWhat Makes a Good Joke?‚Äù: Can it Be Funny?
section: Where does AI even get its ‚Äúsense‚Äù of humor?
text:
Where does AI even get its ‚Äúsense‚Äù of humor?
This leads me to wonder: where does AI‚Äôs humor actually come from? Is it just a bunch of algorithms trained on massive datasets of jokes? Essentially, yes. AI learns humor by analyzing a huge pool of text‚Äîbooks, articles, websites, social media posts, and of course, jokes. It doesn‚Äôt truly ‚Äúunderstand‚Äù what makes something funny in the way humans do. It‚Äôs more like AI is a super advanced ‚Äúmimic‚Äù that‚Äôs incredibly good at picking up patterns and regurgitating them. The base of what is considered funny comes from human-created content, but AI doesn‚Äôt have the cultural context to make truly original humor.
AI‚Äôs jokes are built on probability. It can take certain elements‚Äîword associations, cultural references, and the structure of well-established jokes‚Äîand piece them together. It doesn‚Äôt know how to innovate in the way a comedian can; it just knows what worked in the past. But as funny as that is, it‚Äôs also a limitation. Humor is often about breaking expectations or delivering a punchline with the right timing or cultural context. AI doesn‚Äôt yet have the ability to understand the subtleties of social or emotional context in the same way humans do.

title: AI‚Äôs Take on ‚ÄúWhat Makes a Good Joke?‚Äù: Can it Be Funny?
section: What surprised me about AI‚Äôs humor? What was AI better at than I expected?
text:
What surprised me about AI‚Äôs humor? What was AI better at than I expected?
What really surprised me about AI, though, is how well it did at observational humor. The joke about procrastination and cat videos? I didn‚Äôt expect AI to pull that off. It actually captured a very human experience‚Äîsomething that feels universal. The fact that AI picked up on this everyday observation and turned it into a solid joke made me realize that while it‚Äôs not perfect, it‚Äôs learning how to read situations and trends in a way that mirrors what makes humans laugh.
It also surprised me how quickly AI can generate jokes. While not every punchline lands perfectly, it‚Äôs able to process information and structure humor in real-time, something that would take a human comedian far more time to write, test, and refine. AI is a quick thinker, even if it lacks the depth to really make a joke feel alive.


Can AI be funny? Yes, but in a different way than a human comedian.
It can replicate basic humor patterns and structure jokes, but it doesn‚Äôt yet have the personal touch or nuanced understanding of why something is funny in a given context. The humor is still very much surface-level, but that doesn‚Äôt mean it can‚Äôt make you smile. It‚Äôs a fun experiment, but for now, human comedians still have the edge when it comes to creativity, timing, and injecting the rich context that makes humor truly memorable.
Would I trust AI to headline my comedy night? Probably not. But was it funnier than I expected? Yea it surprised me.

title: About
text: About this blog

title: AI and Mental Health: Can Machines Help Us Feel Better?
text:
We‚Äôve seen AI take on everything from self-driving cars to writing essays, but can it truly understand human emotions and provide meaningful mental health support? To find out, I explored the world of AI-powered mental health apps to see what they offer, how effective they are, and where they fall short.
I tested several AI-driven mental health tools, including chatbots like Woebot, Wysa, and Replika, and rated their ability to provide emotional support, practical coping strategies, and a sense of connection. Here‚Äôs what I discovered.

title: AI and Mental Health: Can Machines Help Us Feel Better?
section: AI and Guided Mental Health Exercises: Do They Work?
text:
AI and Guided Mental Health Exercises: Do They Work?
Beyond chatbots, AI-powered apps like Youper, Sanvello, and MindDoc provide structured mental health exercises to help manage anxiety and depression.

Youper
Uses AI to help track moods and suggest mindfulness techniques. Rating: 7/10 #### Sanvello Focuses on evidence-based mental health strategies, with guided meditations and journaling prompts. Rating: 8/10 #### MindDoc Offers AI-assisted mood tracking and journaling for people struggling with anxiety and depression. Rating: 6/10


Where do AI Mental Health Apps Succeed

they help users track emotional patterns over time, which can be valuable for understanding mental health triggers
they provide structured coping strageies, such as mindfulness and guided breathing exercises
they offer privacy and accessibility, making mental health tools available to anyone, anywhere



Where do AI Mental Health Apps Struggle

AI can provide generalized advice, but it lacks the nuance of a human therapist
They rely heavily on self guided effort, if you don‚Äôt engage with the exercises, they won‚Äôt be effective
Severe mental health conditions require human intervention, which AI can‚Äôt replace

title: AI and Mental Health: Can Machines Help Us Feel Better?
section: What Makes AI Mental Health Tools Different from Human Therapy?
text:
What Makes AI Mental Health Tools Different from Human Therapy?



download.jpg


The biggest difference between AI driven mental health tools and human therapists is depth and connection
A therapist doesn‚Äôt just provide a list of coping mechanisms, they also listen and provide validation based on clients emotions, history and experiences. While AI follows a structured approach based on recognized patterns. It can suggest deep-breathing exercises when you say you‚Äôre anxious, but it won‚Äôt ask about your childhood or recognize patterns in the way a human therapist would.
AI doesn‚Äôt understand emotional nuance. It can recognize words like ‚Äúsad‚Äù or ‚Äústressed‚Äù but won‚Äôt fully grasp sarcasm, deep emotional pain, or the kind of comfort humans offer through shared experiences. A therapist might read body language, notice a change in tone, or offer a moment of silence‚Äîthings that AI can‚Äôt replicate.
That said, AI still has a role to play. It can provide instant access to support when needed and help users build healthy mental habits. It may not replace therapists, but it can complement traditional therapy by offering tools for managing mental health between sessions.

title: AI and Mental Health: Can Machines Help Us Feel Better?
section: Where Does AI‚Äôs Mental Health Support Come From?
text:
Where Does AI‚Äôs Mental Health Support Come From?



01-risk-of-depressive-disorder.webp


AI mental health tools are trained on thousands of therapy transcripts, psychology research papers, and wellness articles. They recognize patterns in human emotions and provide respinses based on CBT principles, mindfullness tecnhniques, and self help strategies. However, they do not possess genuine human empathy or understanding, they mimic supportive behavior rather than truly feeling it
AI learns from data, not experiences, which means it lacks the depth of human insight. But that doesn‚Äôt mean it can‚Äôt be useful, it just means it should be viewed as a tool rather than a replacement for real human care.

title: AI and Mental Health: Can Machines Help Us Feel Better?
section: What surprised me about AI mental health apps?
text:
What surprised me about AI mental health apps?
Despite their limitations, AI mental health tools were more helpful than I expected in certain areas

AI is great at mood tracking, apps like youper and minddoc provided useful insights into emotional patterns, which coukd ve valuable for self reflection
AI responses felt more human than I expected, some chatbot interactions felt genuinely warm and engaging
Instant support is a big plus, AI is available 24/7, which is a major advantage for people who need immediate comfort

title: AI and Mental Health: Can Machines Help Us Feel Better?
section: Can AI Really Help with Mental Health?
text:
Can AI Really Help with Mental Health?



psychology-therapy-isometric-illustration_1284-58097.avif



Yes - but with limitations
AI mental health tools can provide valuable support, offer coping strategies, and help users track emotions, but they don‚Äôt replace the deoth, understanding, and personal connection of humab therapists.
For mild anxiety, stress management, or general emotional well-being, AI-driven apps can be a great starting point. But for deep emotional struggles, complex mental health conditions, or anyone in crisis, human interaction is irreplacable.
Would I trust AI as my sole therapist? Not yet. But am I impressed by how much it can assist in daily mental health maintenance? Absolutely.
AI in mental health isn‚Äôt about replacing human connection‚Äîit‚Äôs about enhancing accesibility and providing support when we need it most. And in that sense, AI might help us feel a little better.

title: AI vs.¬†Human Chef: Can A Chat Bot Really Help You Cook Dinner?
text: Ever stand in front of your fridge, staring at a bunch of random ingredients, trying to figure out what to make for dinner? Well, what if AI could help with that? I decided to test out an AI-powered recipe generator to see what it could come up with based on the contents of my fridge. I inputted a list of common ingredients‚Äîleftover chicken, bell peppers, onions, spinach, and some pantry staples‚Äîand let the AI work its magic. Here are some of the dishes it suggested, and how I think they‚Äôd turn out:

title: AI vs.¬†Human Chef: Can A Chat Bot Really Help You Cook Dinner?
text:
AI vs.¬†Human Chef
A human chef‚Äôs creativity, experience, and ability to understand the nuances of flavor go far beyond what any AI could currently replicate. When a chef enters the kitchen, they rely on more than just a list of ingredients. They have the ability to sense balance‚Äîwhat flavors need to be adjusted, what textures will complement each other, or even how the dish might be presented to enhance the overall experience. A human chef might intuitively add a splash of lemon juice to brighten up a dish or adjust the seasoning based on how the ingredients come together while cooking. On the other hand, AI lacks this kind of sensory feedback. It doesn‚Äôt have taste buds, nor does it have years of experience fine-tuning recipes and techniques. It works by drawing from patterns in the data it‚Äôs been trained on‚Äîrecipes from cookbooks, food blogs, cooking websites, and countless other sources. This means that while AI can come up with perfectly acceptable dishes based on what ingredients are available, it doesn‚Äôt understand how those dishes will feel once they‚Äôre put together. There‚Äôs no personal touch in its cooking, no instinct to elevate a dish by making a tiny change, like adding a pinch of a specific spice at the right moment.



43ee1cafca2f947f0be0d94aeff0fc26-chef-cartoon-profession.png

title: AI vs.¬†Human Chef: Can A Chat Bot Really Help You Cook Dinner?
text:
What surprised me
What surprised me most was how well the AI was able to suggest meals using basic ingredients. It didn‚Äôt just throw out a random combination, but instead, it took common recipe structures and applied them intelligently to the ingredients I had. For example, the stuffed bell peppers seemed like a creative take, and I honestly didn‚Äôt expect the AI to come up with such a thoughtful idea from what I gave it. It showed me that, while AI isn‚Äôt going to be a Michelin-starred chef anytime soon, it‚Äôs very capable of proposing ideas that work within the limitations of available ingredients. What‚Äôs more, I was also surprised by how well the AI captured the idea of creating balanced meals. It recognized that chicken, veggies, and cheese are often used together and suggested combinations that made sense. The dishes, while basic, didn‚Äôt seem off-putting or odd, which is impressive given the AI doesn‚Äôt actually ‚Äútaste‚Äù the food. It uses its vast database of recipe knowledge to predict what flavors and ingredients tend to complement each other based on data rather than experience.

title: AI vs.¬†Human Chef: Can A Chat Bot Really Help You Cook Dinner?
section: Where does AI get its knowledge of what tastes good?
text:
Where does AI get its knowledge of what tastes good?
AI‚Äôs knowledge comes from its massive training on a wide range of data‚Äîespecially culinary resources like recipe websites, cookbooks, blogs, and reviews. It doesn‚Äôt have a direct understanding of taste like a chef does. Instead, it‚Äôs more of a data-processing system that identifies patterns. For example, it can learn that chicken and garlic often go together in Mediterranean cuisine or that spinach is frequently paired with cheese in pasta dishes. It‚Äôs pulling from what‚Äôs worked before, from both common dishes and the success of those dishes based on reviews and feedback, to make predictions about what will taste good. However, without the human element‚Äîthose sensory moments when a chef adjusts their dish based on what‚Äôs in front of them‚ÄîAI can‚Äôt truly ‚Äúknow‚Äù what would taste good beyond the parameters of established culinary patterns. The recipes it creates aren‚Äôt born from experimentation or the chef‚Äôs personal knowledge‚Äîthey‚Äôre the result of statistical analysis of what‚Äôs most likely to work.

The AI-powered recipe generator was surprisingly capable of offering up simple, quick meals that were logical and would likely be enjoyable to eat, though they might lack the depth and creativity a human chef could bring to the table.
It can certainly be helpful when you‚Äôre in a rush, especially when you‚Äôre staring into your fridge and feeling uninspired. But, when it comes to really elevating flavors or taking a meal to the next level, a human chef‚Äôs touch, based on expertise and an understanding of how flavors develop, still holds the upper hand.
AI‚Äôs ability to come up with functional meal ideas shows that it can be a useful kitchen assistant, especially for beginners or those who need to work with limited ingredients. However, when it comes to the magic of cooking and creating something memorable, that‚Äôs where a human chef still shines.



360_F_416275833_h6zdOY2YqTq0VwAhmTvrANehceucH6xp.jpg




Would I trust AI to cook me the most memorable meal of my life? Probably not. But it can for sure be helpful in everyday recipe planning!

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!
